title: Mini printable lathe V2 + Chuck - OpenSCAD version.

description.text:
I've converted the printable Lathe from Sublime into OpenSCAD files. There are some differences, but the parts should be compatible (Except for the gears, those use a different teeth style) The size of the guide-rods/axles and screw holes are adjustable in Util.scad
Also some of the main dimensions can be adjusted in the Util.scad Note that these parts are interexchangeable with the ones from Sublime, unless you change the parameters. If you build this machine from scratch you might want to use thicker guides and a larger guide distance, so the carriage has more stability. Changes:
"X_carriage" is flat on top, so you can print it flat on that side, fixes the overhang.
There might be some printing problems with overhang in the bearing_block. Possible upgrades:
Add step motor mounts so you can make a CNC Lathe.
There is very little clearing between the X carriage and the Z front. Any flex or inaccuracies might cause problems.

Convert SCAD to STL.
Print everything once, except for:
Upright, which you'll need 3 times.
Bevel_gear, you'll need twice.
Hand_crank, you'll also need twice.
You'll need to print 4 mirrored parts, next to the normal ones: "Z_carriage_left", "Gear_lever", "Cam_lever_part_A" and "Cam_lever_part_B" For the chuck, print 4x the planet gear. And 4 jaws. Add 12x 608 bearings.
Add 8M rods for the axles.
Add 6M rods for the guides.
Drill holes larger where I made mistakes ;)
Add a bunch of nuts. TODO: Add part list for the chuck. Add a tool holder (see: www.thingiverse.com/thing:9242 for options)

comments.text: Can anyone explain the point of the planetary gears behind the chuck? I built the chuck just to see how it works but I don't understand why these gears are back there..
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: Are they not to close the jaws evenly?
comments.author: cris11368

comments.text: Do you have a picture of the finished project?
comments.author: Citystars

comments.text: I never finished it. When I started this project I was new to printing. And after printing a few parts I found out that the software for printing was not where I needed it to be. So I spawned the Cura project.
comments.author: Citystars

comments.text: Nice! Wonder how much would the non printed parts for one run, and what you could get away with lathing with it, I don't have machine shop access any more, but usually just need to lathe rather small parts :)
comments.author: Mr_Sheesh

comments.text: Actually, I never got around to print all parts of this thing. When I made this my printer was pretty new to me and I had trouble getting the parts to come out right. Now I know I can print this fine, but I also gained access to 2 real lathes.
comments.author: Mr_Sheesh

comments.text: So how is the progress?  :)
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: The bearings fit! I was waiting to print a few parts before I got that measurement correctly. I should have the X carriage done soon. I didn't print any of the gears yet.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: I've started to print it (finally) I'm still waiting for a few parts to end up in the mail.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: How goes the printing?
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Printing parts of the chuck right now. I had to modify the carriage parts a bit more for my 12mm rods (needs to be a lot wider), and getting those hole dimensions just right took a few tests. I also had to put printing on hold for a while because my cat kept climbing into my printer during prints. (solved now with a few cat shields around my printer)
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: For anyone attempting to print this chuck version, watch out, the piston might be to large in the current version. My first print didn't fit inside the base. I've made it a bit smaller and now it fits.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Just so you know there was an issue with the four jaw chuck. It turns out I had put up some of the parts mirrored. Depending on when you got the files the Face is mirrored and maybe even the piston. I only fixed them today so you may want to make sure the curved slots are facing the right direction or it will be really hard to tighten.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Now I'm not sure if I modeled those parts right, but I already printed them (still waiting for my long enough bolts to arrive).
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: Yes but the jaws should tighten when you turn the face clockwise and the body counter clockwise. My three jaw chuck was always correct. It was the four jaw one I had never printed and you used that was backwards.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: Update!
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: I know it's a work in progress but it would still be nice to have the stl's. I myself can't open a scad files.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: For the SCAD files: http://www.openscad.org/http://www.openscad.org/ runs on Linux/MacOS and Windows. For Ubuntu it's even in the repositories.
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text:
The openSCAD from the repo's does not work AT ALL. The one I compiled my self 6months ago does work, but its sooooo slow and I really hate having to collect files from all over the web just to export an stl. If all the info is not in one file I don't want it. I also really like having a tactical feeling interface (I
Ã¢Â€Â™m an artist not a programmer) and having to go through a text document every time I want to make a change does not work for me. I would rather be able to click five items, press "G" to grab them, then "X" "Y" or "Z" for the direction then a number and it moves all of them at once. It feels like y
ou are actually working with a real object.
comments.author: Daid

comments.text: I'm still working on this. Progress isn't as fast as I've hoped, but I'm getting there. I fixed most of the issues you mentioned (except for the clearing between the X carriage and the Z carriage front, which might or might not fit depending on the quality of your prints)
comments.author: SayNoToMakerbot

comments.text: It would be neat to have a world map with the approximate locations of where every part and ancestor etc came from for things like this
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: I havent seen it done before but I'm sure this could be done with version control (svn, git etc). OpenScad files are essentially code afterall.
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: I have been following this project with rapt attention!
comments.author: triffid_hunter

comments.text: Now that it is written in OpenScad, would be nice to have the thing on github. That would allow update notifications and tracking.
comments.author: triffid_hunter

comments.text: Good work. I'm sure it will start to evolve a lot faster now.

title: BMW E46 3-Series Convertible Guide Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: UPDATE:  V3 Released!
This version is resistant to warping and stronger!  Upgrade ASAP!

These replace the small plastic guides that help push the cloth top inwards (away from the hinge). The OEM tend to get stuck and can damage the top.
They should be able to stand up to the heat, but if you are in a really hot area watch them closely. If you can print in ABS that would probably be best.
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5q0mXhTKPbw

Scale to 25.4 or use the DAE format.
The skinny protrusion should point to the front of the car.
NOTICE:
THESE PARTS ARE DISTRIBUTED IN THE HOPE THAT IT WILL BE USEFUL, BUT WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY. THEY ARE PROVIDED "AS IS" WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, EITHER EXPRESSED OR IMPLIED, INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. I love the Open Brushless Gimbal by turbi but wanted a 3-axis version for my DJI inspired drone. I used turbi's files and changed most of the parts to this version. I use 2208 motors and a storm32 BGC which works great for my GoPro Hero3.
The balls are from a standard DJI set. (DJI H3-3D Standard Version Part42 Damping Shock Absorber Ball) The Bolts I used are stainless steel:
3x M3 x 20mm HEX button head (for the motor clamps)
1x M3 x 20mm HEX button head (for the arm1-arm2 connection)
4x M3 x 8mm HEX button head (for the motor arm3)
4x M3 x 6mm HEX flat head (for the GoPro case) I added some additional snapshots of the assembly. I only use the 16 x 19 mm mounting holes of the motors. The housing of the motor is clamped in the different parts. On request I also added the 123dx design file so you can build further on this design. Short action video here: https://youtu.be/80s-3GhD2zk Enjoy!

title: The Armadillo - A Case of Two Halves
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Following on from the success of the Nested Birdhouse (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116288), I thought I would push the nested small footprint concept a little further, with a printable case. Use it as a lunchbox, purse, briefcase, clutch bag, backpack, fashion accessory etc, you decide. http://youtu.be/vWCLyMZZcQE http://www.gyrobot.co.uk
http://www.facebook.com/gyrobotuk

Print 2 off without support, it's all in the geometry. Attach the two halves with cable ties or PLA rivets. The hole in the catch is for the addition of a lock, carabiner or bolt etc. You can also attach a shoulder strap to the handle or carabiner. Scale up or down (clearance disclaimer) to suit :
Print cube size for a single half 100 x 105 x 96
Print cube size for two halves (nested) 143 x 130 x 96

• layer_height = 0.2
  • perimeters = 2
  • top_solid_layers = 2
  • bottom_solid_layers = 2
  • fill_density = 0.25
  • nozzle_diameter = 0.35
  • filament_diameter = 1.75

title: Parametric clamping blocks with stairs for CNC
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Parametric OpenSCAD model included. You can customize the following parameters (default value in parenthesis):
  • step height and depth (4mm x 2.666mm)
  • number of steps for the stairs (15) and for the leg (3)
  • step angle (30 degrees)
  • thickness (20mm)
  • hole diameter (8.5mm)
  • hole length (25mm)
  • leg length (70mm)
  • leg's tail thickness (40%)
    • Usage:
  • Place the leg as horizontal as you can (only the tip will touch thanks to the half cylinder)
  • Place the screw as close as the part you can.

Printer:

Kossel Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm per layer

Infill:

20%

Notes: After some tries, I'm ending up using a step size of 4mm x 2.66mm. I tried with half but I was not getting a good grip because of my average print quality. I updated the OpenSCAD model to set the default values to the one I'm using now.

title: Schaltraedchen unten 11 Zaehne fuer Schaltwerke / Rear Derailleur Jockey Wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Unteres Schaltraedchen 11 Zähne passend fuer Shimano Ultegra Schaltwerke und Andere.
One Color und Dual Color Versionen.
Mit Kugellager Einpresswerkzeug.
Kugellager S606RS oder 606-2RS 6x17x6mm erforderlich.

Printer:

CTC Dual

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes: Bei Horizontaldruck 10 Shells, Raft nein, Support ja. Bei Vertikaldruck 2 Shells, Raft ja, Support ja.

Wichtige Einbauhinweise! Zum Kugellager Einbauen, Schaltrad mit der Pfeilseite nach unten auf
eine ebene Fläche legen, Kugellager auf Einschlagbolzen setzen, Zapfenscheibe
auf Kugellager Unterseite aufsetzen und mit Gummihammer vollstaendig einschlagen. Zum Kugellager Ausbauen, Schaltrad mit der Pfeilseite nach oben
auf Distanzring legen, Einschlagbolzen aufstecken und Kugellager mit
Gummihammer herausschlagen.

description.text: Just a simple hommage to the Reprap project. Ice cube tray in the shape of the Reprap logo. So next time you have a 3D printer party (I know you guys do!), make sure you make a few of these...cheers! Not totally sure this would work yet since my Prusa Mendel is not here yet :(, but let me know if it does (or doesn't...) Just wanted to make something fun to start with when I do eventually get my Prusa Mendel... UPDATE: I remade this from scratch (again) in OpenSCAD so it's now Parametric and super precise...and you can fiddle with it. Also, the new version in OpenSCAD is a little different that these renderings. Used some code for the logo shape made by raldrich http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11944

• Just print it out (in 3D of course)
  • Add some water
  • Stick it in the freezer
  • Enjoy a toast to the Reprap group!

This is a laser-cuttable recycle bin inspired by UK Based Sprout Design's product 'Binvention' I just got a request from Sprout Design Ltd to remove the design and I have to admit that it was careless to use someone's trademark without any permission. But at first I was reluctant to do so the because

  • Only the concept was inspired by the company's product and fabrication process and material used is totally different.

  • My intention to share the design was purely non profit and I haven't and am not planning to earn a single penny by selling the design or product itself.
    • However I decided to remove my design since I admire the originality of the product and finally came to a thought that mine shouldn't be the one representing the original concept. Thanks.

Foot to fit the Makerbeam profile.
These are the Makerbeam 10mmx10mm aluminium profile beams.
20cm long. Can be clipped in or slid along to the position you want. First picture shows white SemiFlex and Black NinjaFlex.
SemiFlex is easier to print with but isnt as non slip as the NinjaFlex. Can be printed in any material such as ABS, PLA, NinjaFlex, SemiFlex.
NinjaFlex gives the best result for a non slip foot. I based the foot on the profile of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12450/#files

Prusa I2 heavily modified

.2mm

30%

If people are interested I could break it up into components... EDIT:- Added the small off-hand sabre also. EDIT II: The Phantom Edit:- Added both sabers cut in half for those who want to a flat face for printing.

remixed_from.author: KipK
remixed_from.title: FRSKY D4R-II mount with antenna supports

description.text:
UPDATE: Added FrSKy D4R-ii with sideways antenna mounts This is a set of standard 30.5mm spacing plates suitable for stacking with a Naze32, CC3D, or other standard sized flight controller. It contains a number of variations that I made for different builds I was making.
  • Basic - a simple base plate that is the foundation of the rest
  • Cutout 1 - diamond shaped cutouts to reduce weight and allow for zip ties, etc.
  • Cutout 2 - a simple square cutout pattern
  • Cutout 3 - a more complex cutout pattern with slots for velcro
  • FX799T - for mounting a FX799T 40 channel video transmitter
  • FatShark 600TVL - for mounting this specific camera (remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:650363 by MakerSpatz)
  • FatShark 250mw TX - for mounting the classic FatShark 8-channel transmitter (remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1017788 by EarlPrinter)
  • D4R-ii Sideways - remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:435978 by KipK
    • Also included is an STL of all plates, but I don't recommend printing that one. Please note that I've made most, but not all, of these designs, so if you find issues or errors with the fit, please let me know. This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lCVj99Qv5Ja

Just 11 faces and parametric.
Update
kl bttl mk2.stl slices with one error (at least for me) which adds a layer closing the bottle neck at the top of the inner wall... also, RepG was reporting 20cc! of material needed
Added kl_bttl_mk2 2.stl: radius 30, height 60, walls 1.1mm, 7cc & no slicing error.

The top will need active cooling to print and even like that, it may not print nice :-(
You can go to the "body()" module and set r2 to some little value to help printing the top but THEN... you'll get a huge poly count of 18 faces :-P
The provided stl are supposed to be in the dimensions: 80mm OD, 80mm height and 2mm wall thickness.

author: dvjcodec

description.text: 2 Hammershot Barrels! Barrel2 is my first OnShape designed part. This 5-shot barrel will replace the one on a Hammershot, just with some style. It is a simple design, since I'm still learning how to make features in OnShape. I have not printed this one, and my printers are broken (I cannibalized one to fix the other but failed, so I'm reassembling my first one.) So, if you print this part, please post your make and list my errors so my shame can be complete. Barrel1 is the barrel I have on my Hammershot now. It works great, but it does not hold onto the green ZombieStrike darts well. The old N-Strike series darts work fine. It also interferes with the air-restrictor, so don't dry-fire with this barrel. Also, when finishing this barrel, I dry-fit all the parts before acetone-finishing and the parts fit great. After acetone finishing I needed to file open the two guide slots that fit the wings on the first piece for reassembly. You'll figure out what I mean as you reassemble, I'm sure. There must be an official name for all those parts but I'll just use "Thing on that one thing." NOTE: For anyone who came here earlier and saw another barrel, I apologize. That one was not mine, and I had no part in making it. It was Andrew Schreiber's part found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:140120 I hadn't realized that I saved his file over mine some time ago. Organization, folks. That's one word I don't know yet.

This is a sphere with two Enneper ends.

Version 0.5 of LJBot.
A robot designed to house the Raspberry Pi Model A+ or Zero, two 28BYJ-48 Stepper Motors with ULN2003 Drivers and a hr-sc04 or hy-srf05 ultrasonic distance sensor (srf05 recommended).
Optionally the steppers and drivers can be replaced by a micro gear motor and dual h-bridge driver. Its powered by a cheap USB power bank (the ones that hold a single 18650 battery) that sits on top. You will need 4x m3 bolts/nuts to secure the steppers and 10x dupoint cable to hook it all up.
The Pi only has 2 5V pins, connect those to the motor drivers and either build a splitter or shove a male duopoint cable into the back of one of the female stepper motor ones (see picture).
You'll want to put some tape (e.g. kapton, duct) between the drivers. You'll also want to add a 1k resistor between the 5v echo pin of the ultrasonic module and the 3v3 GPIO on the Pi. To save soldering you can use another dupoint cable (see picture) To attach the rear wheel you may be able to use some 3mm fillament or a 3mm metal pin like I have. A bit of heat from a heat gun helps the metal pin fit if its tight. Some python code I've used is here https://github.com/topshed/ZeroBot
The ring on the top can have a neopixel ring taped under it! TinkerCAD objects
